awd_abstract_narration:
The EarthScope science program supports geoscientific exploration of the North American continent to better understand what it is made of, how it was put together, how it works, and why processes like volcanoes and earthquakes take place.  Understanding the processes shaping the Earth is important for understanding potential hazards that may take place, as well as for characterizing what natural resources may exist.  The EarthScope National Office at the University of Alaska, Fairbanks serves a broad community of stakeholders, including researchers, teachers, students, decision makers, and the general public in facilitating and coordinating activities related to synthesizing and disseminating the scientific discoveries made through EarthScope. 


The EarthScope science program has had a long history of supporting research on the structure and dynamics of the North American continent.  The EarthScope National Office at the University of Alaska, Fairbanks will serve as the nexus for the EarthScope community through the next phase of the EarthScope program.  A major focus of this EarthScope National Office will be to help coordinate and facilitate synthesis of major outcomes from EarthScope research and education and outreach.  In addition to supporting community-derived synthesis activities, the Office will convene a series of synthesis workshops based on topics proposed by the community, and the outcomes of these workshops will be published on the website, as well as provide the foundation for review papers and special journal issues.  The EarthScope National Office will also serve the community through leadership and coordination of a variety of core functions.  The Office will continue to coordinate EarthScope-related activities with GAGE, SAGE, and SAFOD core repository personnel, including providing leadership of the EarthScope Steering Committee.  Another major focus of this EarthScope National Office will be outreach to both the EarthScope scientific community as well as to the broader public through an increased science writing portfolio and a more frequently updated EarthScope website.  Other EarthScope Education and Outreach activities that the Office will continue to support include the EarthScope Speaker Series, Newsletter, and biannual National Meeting.

por.por_cntn:
EarthScope (2003-2018) was a program of the National Science Foundation (NSF) to study the structure, evolution, and dynamics of the North American continent. A variety of geophysical instrumentation was installed across the country to meet EarthScope's scientific goals, and these freely available, high precision data were used in hundreds of scientific publications and remain in active use today. The EarthScope National Office, our  component of the EarthScope program, focused on fostering science collaborations and public sharing of EarthScope scientific results, public outreach and education efforts, and program coordination. The Office worked to collect and synthesize the results of many scientists that described how geological forces have shaped North America's landscape, and to bring these to the public to improve public understanding of our dynamic Earth. More information about the many different facets of the EarthScope program, and its legacy products, are available on the website (https://www.earthscope.org/), which the Office re-factored into a robust legacy form.

From 2015 to 2018, the EarthScope National Office was hosted at the University of Alaska, Fairbanks, and a few key outcomes from this project are the focus of this report. A cornerstone activity of the EarthScope National Office was to establish and support collaborations between scientists, educators, policy makers, and the public. The outcomes of this effort have helped the public experience the exciting scientific discoveries as they were made, and the map-based interface to EarthScope science that we developed provides an ongoing interactive experience to those interested in exploring major outcomes of the EarthScope program.

The expertise, enthusiasm, and findings of the EarthScope community constitute a rich resource for enhancing Earth Science education in formal (K-12, college, university) and informal (parks, museums, media) settings. The EarthScope National Office education and outreach program facilitated dissemination of EarthScope science to the broader scientific community, educators, the public and the media. The ESNO created several outreach tools that remain available to educators, researchers, and the public: the Birthquake program (Figure 1); Science Nuggets and the map interface (Figure 2); and public outreach events (Figure 3).

The EarthScope National Office engaged in teacher training and development of educational materials to help provide K-12 teachers with materials to incorporate in their classrooms. Teaching materials are still available on the EarthScope website (https://www.earthscope.org/education/teaching_resources.html). A series of regional workshops were held between 2008 and 2014, organized by prior EarthScope National Offices in Oregon and Arizona. Between 2018 and 2020, three new workshops were held in Alaska, in collaboration with the Alaska Native Geoscience Learning Experience organization (ANGLE). Information and resources from those workshops is available on the EarthScope webpage: https://www.earthscope.org/education/interpretative_workshop.html  

Another important activity conducted by the UAF EarthScope National Office was to organize and arrange for the EarthScope speaker series and science synthesis workshops, both held across the U.S. The EarthScope speaker series involved supporting travel for 5 EarthScope funded researchers each year to give keynote presentations at colleges and universities to share the outcomes of their research with the broader Earth Sciences community. The ESNO at UAF prioritized expanding the geographic reach of the Speaker series, and by 2018 it had covered most regions within the U.S., including Puerto Rico, and included two locations in Canada and Mexico. This link will allow you to view an interactive Google MyMap interface that includes all locations for the EarthScope Speaker Series between 2008 and 2019. Viewers can select each year to see how the reach of the Speaker Series had expanded through the years:  https://www.google.com/maps/d/edit?mid=1k1gLpuvOhDrmrPI3yP343CYiVg8aBVXJ&usp=sharing

EarthScope science synthesis workshops were organized and supported to host collaborative groups of EarthScope funded researchers, students, and others to synthesize new science insights across discipline boundaries, and to develop education and outreach projects for different regions and topics (Figure 4). Synthesis workshops covered many regions in the U.S. that were foci for deployment of EarthScope instrumentation. Between 2017-2019 the EarthScope National Office at the University of Alaska Fairbanks supported a series of nine EarthScope Synthesis Workshops, each of which brought a small group of scientists together from multiple disciplines (Figure 4). Synthesis Workshops typically involved 15-20 people, intended to help start successful working groups, that produced additional research, papers, or new ideas for future EarthScope-related science projects. The outcomes from those workshops are available here: https://www.earthscope.org/research/synthesis_workshops.html
